descriptionSet.description: This image shows Jawaharlal Nehru and Gandhi sitting on the map of India by the feet of Krishna, who is at the centre of the image, standing atop a lotus flower. Nehru is holding a bejewelled Indian flag with his right hand and touching the feet of Krishna with his left hand. Gandhi is depicted in a thoughtful mood with a spinning wheel in front of him and he is also touching Krishna's feet with his right hand. Krishna wearing shining clothes, a garland and a crown is strewing flowers over Gandhi's head and holding the Indian flag with his right hand. There is a bowl holding a book and other articles in front of Gandhi. The book is labelled 'Gita'. A full moon can be seen in the background.

inscription.text: Published by Imperial Calendar Manufacturing Co., Chandni Chowk.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

rights.text: Copyrighted. Copyright with the original artists and publishers.

hra:item.hra:value: Ramnarain P.

description-en: This image shows Jawaharlal Nehru and Gandhi sitting on the map of India by the feet of Krishna, who is at the centre of the image, standing atop a lotus flower. Nehru is holding a bejewelled Indian flag with his right hand and touching the feet of Krishna with his left hand. Gandhi is depicted in a thoughtful mood with a spinning wheel in front of him and he is also touching Krishna's feet with his right hand. Krishna wearing shining clothes, a garland and a crown is strewing flowers over Gandhi's head and holding the Indian flag with his right hand. There is a bowl holding a book and other articles in front of Gandhi. The book is labelled 'Gita'. A full moon can be seen in the background. (sp)
text-hi: गांधी और कृष्ण प्रकाशक इम्पिरीयल
text-hi: प. जवाहिरलाल नेहरु
text-hi: गान्धी जी
text-en: GANDHI & KRISHNA
text-en: No. 131.
text-en: Published by Imperial Calendar Manufacturing Co., Chandni Chowk.
text-en: Copyright Reserved.
text-en: Ramnarain P.
text-transcription-hi: P. Jawaharlal Nehru Gandhiji
text-transcription-hi: Prakashak Imperial

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Perhaps the deepest performative productivity is achieved through viewers/consumers’ interventions by “modes of image customization – such as the application of glitter or zari (brocade) or the adhesion of paper surrounds or plastic flowers – [these] are also corpothetic extensions that move the image closer to the devotee, transforming the ostensible representation or window into a surface deeply inscribed…” (Sandria B. Freitag) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: It is clear from the extant examples that certain kinds of images lend themselves best to such embellishment, performed itself as an act of devotion. These types of images enable a customization to fit the needs and devotional aspirations of the consumer, and are, by and large, images of gods (whether in advertisements or not) and subjects related to nationalism or equivalent imagery for group identity. The “passionate devotionalism” we have recognized before is played out in its most tangible form here. (Sandria B. Freitag) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Note that fact that Nehru and Gandhi—both sitting with bare-feet on a partially-visible map of India (left un-identified)—are clearly named (in Hindi). Also note that at a later date, the owner or purchaser of this print has embellished it further by embroidering Krishna’s garments and jewelry, as well as the national flag. (Sumathi Ramaswamy) (gs)
